text:
PROFESSOR: The major
component of a relationship

of a faculty to a student is
the best side critique, where

you sit down with a
student, the student

explains where they are in the
process, a drawing or a model.
And you make comments.

And it's a very
fascinating process

because you're very
quickly understanding what
the student is trying to do.

And you have to
select what criticism

you can give that's going to
be helpful for the next step.
It happens very quickly.

But it's an essential one-on-one
process between myself

and the students, guiding the
work through the semester.

Perhaps during the
semester, there

are hundreds of desk-side
crits that take place.

Often in this class,
there's 13 people.

I will try to see 13 people
in one afternoon and sometimes
once or twice a week.

So by the end of the
semester the student

has received maybe 20
25 desk-side crits.

So today you're
seeing one of those.

STUDENT: So last time
I talked with you,
I had this model in that spot.

And I had the idea
of creating a wall,

but making
penetrations within it.

And what I started to do was
go from a very square form

or orthogonal form to
creating more nicer shapes

and just creating a
stepping here for example.

We also discussed the
idea of an alleyway here.

And the trees that are
on the site right now

are the ones that I
put up to figure out

whether I want to
cut down a tree

or not or how I can
work with the trees.

And you know me
pretty well by now.

And you know that I don't
want to cut down trees.
So I'm working to preserve them.

And in this case, I cut
into it a little bit.

And instead of having
an alleyway, I just

I decided that I'd have a
secret garden in the back

here and then create
a balcony in there.

So there'd be a balcony
here from the second floor.

And out here would be a
secret garden kind of thing.

And this idea of having a arcade
would be present here as well.
PROFESSOR: Would be here also.
STUDENT: Here too.

[INAUDIBLE] And I was
working with that idea

and seeing how it can just
give you the space maybe.

And so when one of the ideas
of this model here that Jake

suggested to me was the
idea of a footbridge
just crossing that.

And since I'm
working with elderly,

I think it would be very nice
to have a footbridge here

so that they won't have to
go all the way down and then

getting another elevator
or take another ramp up.
They can just cut across here.

And since I'm thinking of having
a screen here or a theater

space out here for
outdoors, I could

have people lining up
here and looking in there.

Or having screenings
of films and things

like that, this would
be another seating area.

And we could have a speaker
system or something fixed up
there.

So right now, I feel I
feel set on how I'm doing.

Something actually,
a minor detail

that was suggested to me, simply
from the shapes that I had,
was having a lower window here.

And since this is going to
be my more private space,

private building versus
the and quieter building,

versus a louder more
social space here,

I like the idea of having
those windows be right

at the very bottom
in that level.

PROFESSOR: Which means that
this is a two-story space?

STUDENT: That
would be one story.

PROFESSOR: But with light's
going down in below?
STUDENT: Yeah.

PROFESSOR: So inside
this is a space?
STUDENT: There will be, yeah.

I imagine that being
either where the infants

would be in my daycare
center or just a place
where people can go and sleep.
Children, elderly can sleep.
And I don't know.

It's just a minor
touch, but just

the shape that I had
from that cardboard.

Because they didn't
match, I just put it in.

And I realized that it
suggested something to me.

PROFESSOR: But the
point is there would
be a slot of light behind that.

Or are you just getting
light into this level?

STUDENT: Yeah, the only
light will be coming,

natural light will be
coming soon from the floor.
That was a minor detail.

But in terms of I don't
know penetrating this space,

I decided I would
probably include this tree
into the actual building.

I think people from the street
level, this being your street,

part of it was the
tourist going that way.

I like the way that it's taking
this out a little bit invited

people in here and
showed them the way

I've had to enter this
building, including the tree.

And here, I have
the same concept,

that I could include
this tree, the trees.

Before Tuesday, I
hadn't put the trees in.

And I just plunked
all my objects here.

But once that I put the trees, I
started thinking, well, maybe I
could do something like that.

And I realized that I would
just lose the whole idea I had

of relating to the street and
having that right angle right
there.

So I see that the only
solution for those shoes

would be to just include
them in the building.

One of my ideas is to
create a patio area.

And that one, that would
be a patio area for eating
and things like that.

And you mentioned to me
creating a secret garden here
on the left.

And the entrance
would be somehow

having to do with
entering through here
going through the building.

And looking at these
two trees, this

is a gateway to enter
into this space.

So I'm imagining that
they will create a gateway

to enter in here, where there'll
be a playground, some swing

sets, tables for I don't know,
two elderly gentlemen to play

chess, just these images I
have in my head right now.

I just imagine bushes right
now, separating that space

so that people walking
by know it's there,

and then question,
how do I get in there,

and realize that they actually
have the right to go in there
because this is a public space.

So that's what my basic
idea is right now.

PROFESSOR: If I'm coming down
the street for the first time,

do you see me coming into
this space or into here,
as the entrance?

STUDENT: Well, I think this
would be more prominent.

And I think more people
will enter in here at first
and then find out what this is.

This is going to be the
central space for my design.

And yes, I think that I had to
stick the wall out a little bit

here because there had to
be a way to invite people

into this building as well,
even though it's my quieter

building for study,
for sleeping,
and taking care of infants.

Whereas here is the dining
and the teaching kids

more creative arts
things like that.

So I am hoping
people enter here.

But I do agree that
that is permanent there,

and that maybe I should
suppress it a little.
PROFESSOR: All right.
I got it.

First of all, the
evolution from this to this

is very successful
because I think

you're starting to develop an
architecture language in this,
which needs obviously more work.

But nevertheless, it's
taking the rough form

into something
that's more precise.
And I think it's good.

The notion of a ramp
that moves through this

and across and over, which
is a new idea since before,
is very powerful.

Just so you know, the
normal ramp is 1 to 12.
And this is probably not that.
But that's OK.
That's a handicap.
That's not necessarily-

But the notion of the ramp
being the thing that moves me

through this, at least
to a certain extent,

I think is a very
powerful notion.

Some comments-- the idea that
this is still covered and light

is coming into this,
I think it's powerful.

But I'm not so sure it's
necessary to continue it
in the same way.

For instance, here, it could
be outside this walkway

or slightly covered, but
not necessarily heated,

where this one might
be a heated space.

So I could come in
into a heated building,
and then uncovered and come out.

And maybe I'd go back into it,
as opposed to it completely
be covered as you show it here.

STUDENT: I showed it in
section 2, that idea right.

PROFESSOR: Well, it
could be that you need--

first of all, you
need this continuity,

which I think is very
powerful of the path through

or the journey
through the building
to hold together the pieces.
So that's very positive.

Then the question is
the magnitude of it.

And it could be that this is
overboard just a little bit.
And you could draw back on it.

At the same time, I think
you very ingeniously,

have figured out a way
of leading this to this

by making this little
place for the tree, which

I think is terrific,
and producing
the little secret garden.

But where I don't think
it works is where you
think of this as being covered.

I think the building,
somewhere in here stops.

And you go outside
into this space.

And this guy, this little
space is to the street.
This one is to the building.

So maybe in there is a bench
or two so I can sit on.

Or in fact, all along this might
be benches as a public place.

This is given over
to the street.

The other is given
over to the building.
So you move in.

Now that brings me
to the, and that's
why I asked you the question.

You have a very subtle,
but important problem
of architecture.

And that is that you do
have two entrances really.

There's this, which
is very major,

and there's this it's
important for you, but is not
as major probably, as this.

That would say for me,
that because there's

a directionality here
that you're working with,

that you need to
make some forms.
Can I do something with this?
STUDENT: Yeah, please.

PROFESSOR: You need to
do something with this,

not that necessarily,
but something

like that, that directs me into
this space a little bit more
forceful.

Even to the point where
in the most extreme--
can I have a piece of some toys?
This is extreme.
But even to the point--
I don't mean it like this.

Even to the point where it
says, I come to this point,

and I'm slipping
into the space here.

At the same time,
I can go in here.

But this is probably
the one that I

think I'm going to go into
if I don't know the building.

So I think you need to
pronounce that more.

And I'm leading up
to something here

because the
directionality of this

could be exploited more
than what you've done.

Because there is
this to work with,

just as you've been
working with that.

However, at the
same time that I say

that, it seems to me that
coming into this space

with this wonderful
ramp, which is

a two-story or
three-story space,

I can imagine light slipping
down alongside of it,

is also important,
and even to the point

where this ramp might have just
slightly turned to pick me up.

So I come in when I
know the building,
or come out, by the way.
It's not only going in.
It's coming up.

So I come in or I go
out through this ramp

that is a clear
kind of definition--

I talked to every day
about paths and places.

This is the clear
journey of a path

moving through your environment
and coming down into something.

So all I'm saying is watch out
here that you don't overdo it.
You need to get us in.

But you need us to get
us in there even more.

And you're not there yet, in the
sense that you have worked over
there yet.
So it probably will happen.

Incidentally, I think it's
incredibly sensitive of you
to try to save the trees.

And that's a real plus
and not always very easy.

Now, the form that you're
working with in here,

the forms is terrific,
except the next go

round you may find that
this is not all glass.

And for the kids, this
is the daycare up here.

This may be a
playground for them.

And therefore, I could move
out into that space from there.

So it doesn't mean
you don't do this.

It may mean that at this corner,
the corner is a good place,

I go out into a roof
garden here for the kids.

Otherwise, they don't
have a place to play.
Or they might play down there.

But they could still
have a place here as long
as it's protected, obviously.

But it's a kid little hangout
or a little secret place,

which is kind of neat up
in the sky if I were a kid.

And you can look out
and watch people.

STUDENT: You can have slumber
parties inside of them.

PROFESSOR: So there's
a lot of privacy.

And as we've said before, as you
go up, things are more private.

So this makes this daycare
for the kids very private.

And almost like, if you wish,
they are viewers of the street.

They watch people
go back and forth.

Now let's move over
to here because I
think that's important.
STUDENT: My problem area.

PROFESSOR: Yeah, it's
your problem area.

But it's the problem area
because you haven't done it.

But I think there's
a major piece here.

If I'm reading this right,
this is still that wall, right?
STUDENT: Yes.
PROFESSOR: And the tree is here.
And the other tree is in here.

And there's another
tree back here, right?

STUDENT: Yeah, and a
little [INAUDIBLE]..
PROFESSOR: Another little tree?
OK, good.

And then there's a
wall back in here.

Two things that you
might consider-- you

have this the wall that we
talked about and in the opening

I'm going through, and we
talked about all of this.
And I'm going under.

And I mentioned that we
need to have some kind
of a way of getting us--

there's a tree in
here, by the way,
somewhere, into this space.
All that's fine.

And above it then,
is this passageway
that is coming to a point.

And then either by
ramp in the same way,
it comes down into this.

And it would be
interesting if there's

a way you could make that ramp
then part of seats, which then

relates to your
amphitheater, which
is here if you can do that.

So then I have a continuous
experience coming down.

If you can't make that
happen, then maybe
this ramp comes along across.

And there's some major
kind of spiral stairs

like the one over the Memorial,
Stahl Drive, that gets me
down and out into this space.

Because this is really the
center of the life for you
and outside.
This is inside.

But the point that I wanted to
make is that the building is--
let me just move this--
it's here.

And you have this space
that we talked about before.

It seems to me
still, that sense,

there's a tremendous
notion here that there's

a wall of different kinds that
are coming along the street,

that we still might
see something here

that is not obviously
nearly as opaque as this,

maybe much lower, but it's
collected to this in some way

so that the corner is
not turned drastically.
Maybe this is low.

Maybe this is translucent,
I can see through.

And then this
becomes, which is what

I think you want, something of
a secret garden to hang out in,

which is not necessarily
connected to this.
Or it could be.

Now here comes the piece that
I think could be interesting.

If these guys, these
trees are here,

then maybe this
building does this.
And this part is outside.

So that when I'm
in this space, I'm
letting the trees to be outside.

And I'm also providing a way
of getting into this building
or out.

STUDENT: On the street, or
this would still be connected?

PROFESSOR: No, this
would still be here.

But all I'm saying
is that in order

to keep that tree,
what you want to do,
maybe it's part of this space.

And it's also a way of
making the transition

as another entrance or
exit from this building

into the space, as
opposed to, which

is what you were
suggesting, which

was to corral it or build
something around it basically,
and then hope that--

it's not going to live
inside by the way.
It has to be outside somehow.

You could make a
courtyard out of it.

But I think you
got a bum pencil.

I think the courtyard is too
close to the other courtyard
to make any sense.

So instead of a courtyard
here and a courtyard here,
it might be combined.

Now in the best
world, maybe this tree

is more accurate,
the two trees so

that this is more of a tiny
triangular chunk out of this,

as opposed to the
one I just drew.
But I don't know.
We have to see what it is.
And then you still have that.

So now I have this kind
of relationship from this.

And by the way, you said
there'd be a hedge here.

So now I'm saying
there's some kind

of translucent wall in
here, I can see through,
I can see people.
There playing chess, et cetera.

But maybe there's
something else in here.

There's water, I
don't know what,
that acts is the focus of this.

But because the trees
are marching along--
I'm putting another one here.

This space is marching
into this one.
And then I'm into that.

And by the way, even better, if
I could figure out a way that

I can, at this point, see
right through this building
and out into the amphitheater.

So then I get a
continuous experience

between the hardness,
I'll say for the moment,

of the amphitheater,
to the inside,

to transition into
this very quiet garden,
which might have water.

I guess we talked
about that before.

So there's different
experiences along the way.
But they're all connected.

There's two connections
that you got.

One is the screen, we'll
call it, along the street.

And the other one is
your ingenious ramp

that was moving through
down and around into this.

Now tell me again,
I've forgotten.

Is this guy two
stories building.
STUDENT: It'll be two or three.
I'm not sure yet.

I was envisioning three
because I was seeing again,

this kind of stepping I
wanted to clear because

of the echo of it, and
also mimic as a stadium,
as an amphitheater.

But until I tackle
that, I don't know.

But I was envisioning
three stories.

I talked to you last time
about hierarchy and the story

I was missing out on the
hierarchy of the two buildings
at the same height.
So I might lose that.

But maybe if I can emphasize
this as being a central space,
then that would be my hierarchy.
And I won't need to-

PROFESSOR: Well, what we
talked about before too is that

the roofs, if it's a
second-story building,

which is going to interfere
with this thing coming across,

so in this thing,
they'd sit behind it--

could be seats for
the amphitheater.

And then the seats down here
also, fitting up the theater.

So that the side of this
building, although it's got

transparency moving
into the space,

but the side of that
building is actually

moving up from the landscape,
making a kind of a bowl shape.

And I think that's
very powerful,

because you're putting an
incredible amount of energy
or activity on this.

In other words,
when, we're all done,

this is probably
the place where you

come to have an event
obviously, but also
kind of a meeting place.

And the kids might play
in here and run around.

This is probably
the quiet place,

as you said, play
checkers or whatever.
And it's wonderful.

In fact, maybe this even becomes
more green in relationship
to this.

STUDENT: I'm wanting somewhere
that there's sunlight.

And mostly, sunlight would
be coming in through here.

I'm also thinking of stepping
it down towards this building

so that maybe this light
could go right in that corner
and enter into this space.
PROFESSOR: Well, I'd be careful.
I'll tell you why.
You're defining this space.

And it does have two
good definitions.

This-- by having the
wall up at that point,

there's a slippage
there, which is fine--
makes it more contained.

If you start
stepping it down, you

may start to lose some
of that containment.

And this is different
kind of a space in this.

Here, this backyard space,
little secret garden it's fine.
That slips out.

I'm not so sure that this one
wants to slip out as much.

But I would invite you to
take the model and a Luxor

lamp or any light
and follow the sun.
Yeah, that's perfect.
That's the sun.

And follow the sun
and see what it does.

Because the next step
would be to consider

if the sun, for instance,
is coming over the building,

then on this side
of the- where am I?

No, that's got--
the event building,

there might be panels that
can divert the light down
into here.

Or if the sun is
coming this way,

there might be panels on the
side of the building that's

vertical that can divert, bounce
the light that we talked about.

I doubt you're going to get
much sun down into here period.

But you are going to
probably get sun up above.

So these panels, maybe are up
here, that are catching the sun
and bringing it down.

So there's a whole other
kind of design notion

here that we haven't
talked about.

All this, let's
assume it's all done.

Then there may be up around
this building, which is going
to be a screen on this room.

But even above
that, there might be

panels that are bouncing
light all the way around

at a certain height, which is
another form of architecture,
sky form actually.

And I'm catching the
sun bouncing light, down

into what I think is your
major place, this one.
Not here.

This is cool,
green, shady, quiet.

This is alive, light, hot,
sunny, just the opposite.

But beyond that--
and of course, we

should be using the
sun as much as we can.

Beyond that, this is another
architectural continuity.

So it's not only bouncing the
sun, but it's something else.

STUDENT: I like the
way that the site,

or the way that this is laid
out right now is hugging itself.
This is quiet.

And then there's the busy
activities in the sunroom.

It feels like it's
getting there, continues,
it'll get better.

PROFESSOR: I think the
organization is just right,
the way you filled it.

I think the architectural
language that you're starting
to develop is the beginning.

I would move on now
quickly to here.

And I happen to know
from experience,

that this ramp is not going
to be as nice as you think.

It's going to take a little
working to make it work.

But it's a powerful notion, that
the ramp is as an organizer.
